message_text:
Paper Title: Automated unit testing of agent systems Paper Abstract: Agent technology has been increasingly used for building sophisticated applications. Agents are autonomous and complex, making their correctness difficult to be verified. Although there has been some work on testing some aspects of an agent system, there is a lack of research for comprehensively testing an agent system automatically from a low-level stage.
This thesis explores an approach for automatically testing agent systems. In the approach an automated testing framework has been developed to allow for completely automated unit testing of an agent system, from generation of test cases, through automated implementation of test harnesses, running of test cases and production of a detailed report. Following the principle of model based testing, the approach tests each unit in the agent system against its details as specified in the unit’s design descriptor, which is part of the AOSE (Agent Oriented Software Engineering) design model of the system. An algorithm has been developed to comprehensively generate test case inputs taking into account value ranges of, and relationships between input variables. Test cases are executed to detect potential faults in a unit under test, based on a fault model we have developed that describes possible problems in different kind of units. Although test cases are generated automatically, we also allow for adding manual test cases with particular values to verify certain situations.
The evaluation results have shown that the tool can reveal previously unidentified problems in a system under test. Some of these problems cause substantial but difficult to detect errors at runtime. Some of the faults detected are false positives, however most of these can be avoided or can come with more precise notifications with the improvements of our testing framework.
 "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Here's what I found about software engineering:

## Overview

Software engineering is a branch of both computer science and engineering focused on designing, developing, testing, and maintaining software applications.(no content)It involves applying engineering principles and computer programming expertise to develop software systems that meet user needs.

## History

In 1968, NATO organized the first conference on software engineering, which addressed emerging challenges in software development and played a key role in formalizing guidelines and best practices for creating reliable and maintainable software.(no content)The term appeared in a list of services offered by companies in the June 1965 issue of "Computers and Automation" and was used more formally in the August 1966 issue of Communications of the ACM.

## Key Institutions

In 1984, the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) was established as a federally funded research and development center headquartered on the campus of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States.

## Professionalism and Ethics

Software engineering professionalism is a movement to make software engineering a profession, with aspects such as degree and certification programs, professional associations, professional ethics, and government licensing.

## Current Statistics

As of early 2025, there are an estimated 47.2 million software developers worldwide, representing a 50% increase from 31 million in Q1 2022.

Here's what I found about software engineering:

## Overview

Software engineering is a branch of both computer science and engineering focused on designing, developing, testing, and maintaining software applications.(no content)It involves applying engineering principles and computer programming expertise to develop software systems that meet user needs.

## History

In 1968, NATO organized the first conference on software engineering, which addressed emerging challenges in software development and played a key role in formalizing guidelines and best practices for creating reliable and maintainable software.(no content)The term appeared in a list of services offered by companies in the June 1965 issue of "Computers and Automation" and was used more formally in the August 1966 issue of Communications of the ACM.

## Key Institutions

In 1984, the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) was established as a federally funded research and development center headquartered on the campus of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States.

## Professionalism and Ethics

Software engineering professionalism is a movement to make software engineering a profession, with aspects such as degree and certification programs, professional associations, professional ethics, and government licensing.

## Current Statistics

As of early 2025, there are an estimated 47.2 million software developers worldwide, representing a 50% increase from 31 million in Q1 2022.

## Test Case in Software Testing

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about test cases in software testing:

### Definition

In software engineering, a test case is a specification of the inputs, execution conditions, testing procedure, and expected results that define a single test to be executed to achieve a particular software testing objective, such as to exercise a particular program path or to verify compliance with a specific requirement.

### Key Components

A well-structured test case typically includes:

- A unique identifier for the test case and the test case objective
- The exact steps to perform and the expected outcome and how to determine whether it has been realized
- Conditions that must exist or preparation required before test execution
- Whether this test case is automated or not and, if so, how

### Importance and Benefits

Test cases underlie testing that is methodical rather than haphazard.(no content)Formally defined test cases allow the same tests to be run repeatedly against successive versions of the software, allowing for effective and consistent regression testing.(no content)In order to fully test that all the requirements of an application are met, there must be at least two test cases for each requirement: one positive test and one negative test.

### Test Suites

In software development, a test suite, less commonly known as a validation suite, is a collection of test cases that are intended to be used to test a software program to show that it has some specified set of behaviors.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Model-based testing"

Links: [{"title":"Model-based testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_testing"},{"title":"Spec Explorer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spec_Explorer"},{"title":"Analytical Performance Modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytical_Performance_Modeling"},{"title":"TargetLink - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TargetLink"},{"title":"Test design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_design"},{"title":"Animal models of depression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_models_of_depression"}]

## Model-Based Testing Results

Here are the search results for "Model-based testing":

### Definition and Overview
Model-based testing is an approach to testing that leverages model-based design for designing and possibly executing tests.(no content)A model can represent the desired behavior of a system under test (SUT).

### How It Works
In some model-based testing environments, models contain enough information to generate executable test suites directly, while in others, elements in the abstract test suite must be mapped to specific statements or method calls in the software to create a concrete test suite.

### Classification
Because test suites are derived from models and not from source code, model-based testing is usually seen as one form of black-box testing.

### Modeling Languages
Typical modeling languages for test generation include UML, SysML, mainstream programming languages, finite machine notations, and mathematical formalisms such as Z, B (Event-B), Alloy or Rocq.

### Deployment Methods
Online testing means that a model-based testing tool connects directly to an SUT and tests it dynamically. Offline generation of executable tests means that a model-based testing tool generates test cases as computer-readable assets that can be later run automatically. Offline generation of manually deployable tests means that a model-based testing tool generates test cases as human-readable assets that can later assist in manual testing.

### Benefits
The effectiveness of model-based testing is primarily due to the potential for automation it offers. If a model is machine-readable and formal to the extent that it has a well-defined behavioral interpretation, test cases can in principle be derived mechanically.

Web search results for query: "Agent-oriented software engineering"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Agent-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"INGENIAS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INGENIAS"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-Agent_System"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Service (systems architecture) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_(systems_architecture)"},{"title":"AI-assisted software development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-assisted_software_development"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Service-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service-oriented_Software_Engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Agent-oriented software engineering:

## Overview

Agent-oriented software engineering (AOSE) is a software engineering paradigm that arose to apply best practice in the development of complex Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) by focusing on the use of agents, and organizations (communities) of agents as the main abstractions.

## Context and Importance

With the advent of biologically inspired, pervasive, and autonomic computing, the advantages of, and necessity of, agent-based technologies and MASs has become obvious. The field emerged from research on intelligent systems and distributed problem solving.

## Key Characteristics

Four key notions that distinguish agents from arbitrary programs are: reaction to the environment, autonomy, goal-orientation and persistence. Additionally, agents have flexible behavior: reactive, proactive, social.

## Methodologies and Frameworks

One notable example in the field is INGENIAS (Engineering for Software Agents), an open-source software framework for the analysis, design and implementation of multi-agent systems (MAS), which adopts a model-driven engineering (MDE) approach.

## Related Paradigms

It's worth noting that agent-oriented programming (AOP) is a programming paradigm where the construction of the software is centered on the concept of software agents, which is closely related but distinct from the broader software engineering discipline.

Links: [{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Agent-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"INGENIAS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INGENIAS"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-Agent_System"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Service (systems architecture) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_(systems_architecture)"},{"title":"AI-assisted software development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-assisted_software_development"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Service-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service-oriented_Software_Engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Agent-oriented software engineering:

## Overview

Agent-oriented software engineering (AOSE) is a software engineering paradigm that arose to apply best practice in the development of complex Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) by focusing on the use of agents, and organizations (communities) of agents as the main abstractions.

## Context and Importance

With the advent of biologically inspired, pervasive, and autonomic computing, the advantages of, and necessity of, agent-based technologies and MASs has become obvious. The field emerged from research on intelligent systems and distributed problem solving.

## Key Characteristics

Four key notions that distinguish agents from arbitrary programs are: reaction to the environment, autonomy, goal-orientation and persistence. Additionally, agents have flexible behavior: reactive, proactive, social.

## Methodologies and Frameworks

One notable example in the field is INGENIAS (Engineering for Software Agents), an open-source software framework for the analysis, design and implementation of multi-agent systems (MAS), which adopts a model-driven engineering (MDE) approach.

## Related Paradigms

It's worth noting that agent-oriented programming (AOP) is a programming paradigm where the construction of the software is centered on the concept of software agents, which is closely related but distinct from the broader software engineering discipline.

Web search results for query: "Unit testing software"

Links: [{"title":"Unit testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_testing"},{"title":"Software testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_testing"},{"title":"List of unit testing frameworks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unit_testing_frameworks"},{"title":"Smoke testing (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoke_testing_(software)"},{"title":"Dynamic testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_testing"},{"title":"Regression testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_testing"},{"title":"Black-box testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-box_testing"},{"title":"Monkey testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monkey_testing"},{"title":"Test harness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_harness"},{"title":"Software testing tactics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_testing_tactics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about unit testing software:

## Definition

Unit testing, also known as component or module testing, is a form of software testing by which isolated source code is tested to validate expected behavior.(no content)Unit testing describes tests that are run at the unit-level to contrast testing at the integration or system level.

## Purpose and Benefits

Unit testing finds problems early in the development cycle, including both bugs in the programmer's implementation and flaws or missing parts of the specification for the unit.(no content)Unit testing enables more frequent releases in software development by testing individual components in isolation, allowing developers to quickly identify and address issues, leading to faster iteration and release cycles.

## How It Works

During development, a programmer may code criteria, or results that are known to be good, into the test to verify the unit's correctness, and during test execution, frameworks log tests that fail any criterion and report them in a summary.(no content)The most commonly used approach is test - function - expected value.

## Test Organization

A battery of test cases can be built to produce the desired coverage of the software being tested, and formally defined test cases allow the same tests to be run repeatedly against successive versions of the software, allowing for effective and consistent regression testing.

## Testing Frameworks

Unit testing frameworks are commonly used for unit testing and can also be used for integration and system level testing.(no content)Parameterized tests are supported by TestNG, JUnit, XUnit and NUnit, as well as in various JavaScript test frameworks.

Web search results for query: "Agent technology autonomous systems"

Links: [{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"AI-driven design automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-driven_design_automation"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_flight"}]

Here are the search results for "Agent technology autonomous systems":

## Key Concepts

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence system that can perform complex tasks independently.

## Core Characteristics

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)A specialized subset of intelligent agents, agentic AI, expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.

## Multi-Agent Systems

A multi-agent system is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)The agents in a multi-agent system have several important characteristics: autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Current Applications and Developments

Autonomous agents increasingly interact with IoT devices, enabling smart home systems, industrial monitoring, and urban infrastructure management.(no content)Tools like Cognition AI's Devin aim to create autonomous software engineers capable of complex reasoning, planning, and completing engineering tasks requiring thousands of decisions.

## Recent Developments

A June 2025 Gartner report accused many projects described as agentic AI of being rebrands of previously released products, terming the phenomenon as "agent washing".(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Here's what I found about fault model testing:

## Overview

A fault model is an engineering model of something that could go wrong in the construction or operation of a piece of equipment, from which the designer or user can predict the consequences of this particular fault.(no content)Fault models can be used in almost all branches of engineering.

## Types of Fault Models

There are several common fault model types used in testing:

**Static Faults:**
- Stuck-at fault model: A signal or gate output is stuck at a 0 or 1 value, independent of the inputs to the circuit.
- Bridging fault model: Two signals are connected together when they should not be.
- Open fault model: A wire is assumed broken, and one or more inputs are disconnected from the output that drives them.

**Dynamic Faults:**
- Transition delay fault (or transition fault) model, where the signal eventually assumes the correct value, but more slowly (or rarely, more quickly) than normal.

## Testing Approach

Fault coverage refers to the percentage of some type of fault that can be detected during the test of any engineered system, with high fault coverage being particularly valuable during manufacturing test.(no content)To use a fault model, each input pin on each gate in turn is assumed to be grounded, and a test vector (a collection of bits to apply to the circuit's inputs and expected outputs) is developed to indicate the circuit is faulty.

Here's what I found about fault model testing:

## Overview

A fault model is an engineering model of something that could go wrong in the construction or operation of a piece of equipment, from which the designer or user can predict the consequences of this particular fault.(no content)Fault models can be used in almost all branches of engineering.

## Types of Fault Models

There are several common fault model types used in testing:

**Static Faults:**
- Stuck-at fault model: A signal or gate output is stuck at a 0 or 1 value, independent of the inputs to the circuit.
- Bridging fault model: Two signals are connected together when they should not be.
- Open fault model: A wire is assumed broken, and one or more inputs are disconnected from the output that drives them.

**Dynamic Faults:**
- Transition delay fault (or transition fault) model, where the signal eventually assumes the correct value, but more slowly (or rarely, more quickly) than normal.

## Testing Approach

Fault coverage refers to the percentage of some type of fault that can be detected during the test of any engineered system, with high fault coverage being particularly valuable during manufacturing test.(no content)To use a fault model, each input pin on each gate in turn is assumed to be grounded, and a test vector (a collection of bits to apply to the circuit's inputs and expected outputs) is developed to indicate the circuit is faulty.

## Summary

✅ **All tasks completed successfully!**

**Paper Classification:** The paper is classified as a **contribution** - it proposes a novel automated testing framework for agent systems.

**7 Triples Identified and Validated:**

1. **Software agent** (uses) - Concept entity representing the autonomous systems being tested
2. **Unit testing** (proposes) - Method that the paper proposes as an automated framework
3. **Model-based testing** (uses) - Method principle used in the testing approach
4. **Agent-oriented software engineering** (uses) - Concept providing the design descriptors used in testing
5. **Test case** (proposes) - Concept for which the paper develops automatic generation algorithms
6. **Software engineering** (uses) - Foundational concept applied to agent system testing
7. **Fault model** (proposes) - Novel concept developed to describe possible problems in agent units

**Validation Result:** ✅ All validation checks passed
- Paper type: contribution
- Entity types: 5 concepts, 2 methods
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct
